verses.text: On the first day of the week, while it was still dark, Mary Magdalene came to the tomb and saw that the stone had been removed from the entrance.
verses.comment: Mary Magdalene being mentioned first shows her special devotion. The day after the Sabbath (the first day) is foundational for Christian worship. The removal of the stone is a physical sign of Christ's victory over death.

verses.text: So she ran and came to Simon Peter and to the other disciple whom Jesus loved, and said to them, "They have taken the Lord out of the tomb, and we do not know where they have laid him."
verses.comment: John calls himself 'the disciple whom Jesus loved.' Peter is named first, indicating his leadership role among the apostles.

verses.text: Peter and the other disciple went out and were going toward the tomb.
verses.comment: Both run to see for themselves, showing the urgency and importance. The 'other disciple' is traditionally understood as John.

verses.text: They both were running together, but the other disciple outran Peter and arrived at the tomb first.
verses.comment: John’s youthful eagerness is contrasted with Peter’s, who still arrives, symbolizing unity between the leadership and love among the apostles.

verses.text: He bent down and looked in, and saw the linen cloths lying there, but he did not go in.
verses.comment: The linen cloths are physical evidence of the resurrection—not of theft, as thieves would not have left them behind.

verses.text: Then Simon Peter came, following him, and went into the tomb. He saw the linen cloths lying there,
verses.comment: Peter enters the tomb first, again reflecting his leadership and authority among the disciples.

verses.text: And the face cloth that had been on Jesus’ head, not lying with the linen cloths but folded up in a place by itself.
verses.comment: The separate, folded face cloth shows intentional care, suggesting that Jesus left the grave-clothes Himself, not hurriedly or by robbers.

verses.text: Then the other disciple, who had arrived first at the tomb, also went in, and he saw and believed.
verses.comment: John is the first to believe in the Resurrection from the physical evidence. Faith is a response to what he sees.

verses.text: For they did not yet understand the Scripture, that he must rise from the dead.
verses.comment: Here, John points to prophecy—although they believed, full comprehension comes with understanding the Scripture. Fulfillment of Old Testament prophecies.

verses.text: So the disciples went back to their homes.
verses.comment: Disciples return, still confused but beginning to believe. The event is private, not public.

verses.text: But Mary stood weeping outside the tomb. As she wept, she bent down to look into the tomb,
verses.comment: Mary’s perseverance in love and devotion is a moving example for all believers. Her sorrow precedes joy.

verses.text: And she saw two angels in white sitting where the body of Jesus had lain, one at the head and one at the feet.
verses.comment: Angels present as witnesses; their positioning echoes the cherubim on the Ark of the Covenant (Exodus 25:18-22)—God’s presence.

verses.text: They said to her, "Woman, why are you weeping?" She replied, "Because they have taken away my Lord, and I do not know where they have laid him."
verses.comment: Her calling Jesus 'my Lord' shows personal devotion. The angels gently question her, preparing her for the Resurrection revelation.

verses.text: When she had said this, she turned around and saw Jesus standing, but she did not know that it was Jesus.
verses.comment: Jesus reveals Himself gradually, as often after the resurrection. Recognition is both physical and spiritual.

verses.text: Jesus said to her, "Woman, why are you weeping? Whom are you seeking?" She, supposing him to be the gardener, said, "Sir, if you have carried him away, tell me where you have laid him, and I will take him."
verses.comment: Misidentification is a common resurrection motif. Jesus’ gentle questions draw out her desire and faith.

verses.text: Jesus said to her, "Mary." She turned and said to him in Aramaic, "Rabboni!" (which means Teacher).
verses.comment: She recognizes Him when He calls her by name—showing the personal connection between Jesus and His followers. In John, recognizing Jesus always requires divine initiative.

verses.text: Jesus said to her, "Do not cling to me, for I have not yet ascended to the Father. But go to my brothers and say to them, 'I am ascending to my Father and your Father, to my God and your God.'"
verses.comment: Jesus’ reference to 'my brothers' shows the new relationship after His Resurrection. His reference to ascending prefigures later teaching on the heavenly ministry.

verses.text: Mary Magdalene went and announced to the disciples, "I have seen the Lord," and that he had said these things to her.
verses.comment: Mary is the first messenger of the Resurrection, showing the importance of witness and spiritual experience.

verses.text: On the evening of that day, the first day of the week, the doors being locked where the disciples were for fear of the Jews, Jesus came and stood among them and said, "Peace be with you."
verses.comment: Jesus’ appearance through locked doors is a sign of His glorified body. His greeting, 'Peace,' recalls the Hebrew 'shalom,' implying reconciliation and spiritual gifts.

verses.text: After He said this, He showed them His hands and His side. Then the disciples rejoiced when they saw the Lord.
verses.comment: He shows His wounds, demonstrating real bodily resurrection and continuity with His crucifixion. This establishes proof and fulfills prophecy.

verses.text: Jesus said to them again, "Peace be with you. As the Father has sent me, even so I am sending you."
verses.comment: Jesus confers His own mission to the disciples, establishing them as authoritative witnesses. This passage is foundational for apostolic succession in the Church.

verses.text: And after He said this, He breathed on them and said to them, "Receive the Holy Spirit."
verses.comment: Jesus imparts the Holy Spirit by His breath, as God gave life in Genesis. This is a direct act of divine authority and sacramental significance for spiritual rebirth.

verses.text: If you forgive the sins of any, they are forgiven them; if you withhold forgiveness from any, it is withheld."
verses.comment: Jesus gives His disciples the authority to forgive sins—a unique power. This supports the understanding of the Church's sacramental ministry and its priestly function.

verses.text: But Thomas, one of the twelve, called Didymus, was not with them when Jesus came.
verses.comment: Thomas, known for his skepticism, becomes a key figure in the demonstration of faith following doubt.

verses.text: So the other disciples were saying to him, "We have seen the Lord." But he said to them, "Unless I see in His hands the mark of the nails, and put my finger into the mark of the nails, and put my hand into His side, I will never believe."
verses.comment: Thomas’ demand for physical proof brings out the importance of the Resurrection as a real, bodily event, not just spiritual.

verses.text: Eight days later, His disciples were inside again, and Thomas was with them. Although the doors were locked, Jesus came and stood among them and said, "Peace be with you."
verses.comment: Eight days implies an early tradition of gathering for worship, possibly a reference to Sunday worship among Christians. Jesus’ greeting repeats His offer of peace.

verses.text: Then He said to Thomas, "Put your finger here, and see My hands; and put out your hand, and place it in My side. Do not be unbelieving, but believe."
verses.comment: Jesus invites Thomas to observe and touch Him—affirming the physical resurrection. Jesus calls for faith based on real witness.

verses.text: Thomas answered Him, "My Lord and my God!"
verses.comment: Thomas’s confession is a direct acknowledgment of Jesus’ divinity. This is one of the clearest statements in the Gospels of Christ as both Lord and God.

verses.text: Jesus said to him, "Have you believed because you have seen Me? Blessed are those who have not seen and yet have believed."
verses.comment: Jesus praises the faith of those who trust without seeing—a model for all future believers, showing that faith is not only sensory but spiritual.

verses.text: Now Jesus did many other signs in the presence of the disciples, which are not written in this book.
verses.comment: John acknowledges the limitations of his Gospel, indicating an oral tradition and authoritative teaching beyond these writings.

verses.text: But these are written so that you may believe that Jesus is the Messiah, the Son of God, and that by believing you may have life in His name.
verses.comment: John’s purpose is explicit: faith in Jesus as Messiah and Son of God brings eternal life—a theme echoing throughout scripture, grounded in witness and teaching.
